We will not be able to spill over into on-demand interventions.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Madam President, more jobs and a better quality of life are the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Europe has many assets to achieve this and finally get out of the economic crisis: a skilled workforce, a strong technological and industrial base, an internal market, a single currency but also and above all, a dynamic and voluntary young generation. I believe that we must build on our young people to revive growth in a sustainable and inclusive way. To do that, we need to push them to undertake. I believe in the importance of instilling entrepreneurship in them. It is a rare commodity that must be promoted because it is the life force of tomorrow's Europe. With this in mind, I would like to stress today the importance of creating an environment conducive to the creation and development of businesses in Europe. In particular, I would like to encourage the development of the Erasmus programme for young entrepreneurs. We need to provide more resources and more local relays because it is a promising program.  It is through these measures that we will be able to make the strategy a reality.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: Madam President, when hearing earlier from, for instance, the Commissioner and the PPE coordinator and other PPE speakers about the importance of the fight against precariousness and the need for quality – not just quantity – of jobs, I was reminded of Molière when he wrote ‘Je vis de bonne soupe, et non de beau langage’. Talk is cheap, but when it comes to actually doing things, there always seems to be a reason why not. What we actually need is a proper implementation of the Temporary Agency Workers Directive, not more abuse of the Swedish derogation by the UK Government. We need EU-level action against zero hours contracts, against 1.4 million people being exploited; and very importantly, Commissioner, we need a fundamental revision of the original Posting of Workers Directive to stop workers in the West Midlands being undercut by what they think is the EU.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. In the resolution voted on today, we highlighted the consequences of neglect in employment and social policy. The omissions that often resulted from the struggle to balance national budgets, which were severely affected by the crisis. Social policy spending is ad hoc and, although necessary, does not bring about long-term change. It is social investment and forms of activation of excluded groups that are expenditure that brings results and benefits, including financial ones, but takes time. The problem is that in times of crisis we do not make long-term investments. For example, we are not investing in ambitious youth education, as this will only bear fruit in a decade. In times of crisis, we think here and now. We forget that a lack of social investment will lead not only to the loss of generations, but to the great impoverishment of European society. The growing problem of poverty is an example that we need to be aware that rapid economic growth does not reduce poverty, despite such a general belief. People who are in poverty need long-term action and assistance to get out of poverty, and economic growth is no longer affecting them, as they are already out of reach of the wave of benefits and employment.  We have many good solutions in Europe, examples where responsible policies, particularly in terms of activating society, bring single-digit levels of unemployment and low levels of poverty. Let us learn from ourselves, let us learn to follow the example of others, adapting ideas to our realities. This will allow us to implement more effectively the main foundation of our EU unity – cohesion policy, which, in the face of... (The President has taken the vote of the Member)

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that the central theme of our debate is that of growth, and we therefore await very carefully what will be the return of Juncker's commitment to investment. But as we await developments in the investment plan, we cannot fail to stress today that it is essential in the short term to indicate instruments that can really be able to support the incomes of the most fragile and weakest people. It is well known that the fall in consumption, for example in the purchase of medicines, but also the fall in food consumption, is returning us to an absolutely serious situation. We have not ...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Madam President, dear colleagues, it has become clear that the Europe 2020 strategy cannot yet bring employment levels up, but in America, which is already out of crisis, the unemployment rate has fallen to 6%. Unemployment in the European Union has fallen by only two percentage points in recent times to 10.7%. The European Parliament's resolution underlines the need to move the tax burden towards more sustainable forms of taxation in order to stimulate growth and job creation, i.e. larger actors with a higher economic weight must also play their part. I think that's an important message. Hungary has been on this path since 2010, with employment rising by 3% and unemployment falling from 10% to 7.6%. I believe that the message of this resolution must be taken into account by all Member States and by the Commission, because citizens are the losers of the crisis and it must end.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Achieving the employment rate target, reducing poverty and social exclusion by 2020 requires a unified political will and real cooperation, both between and within Member States, and between the Member States and the Institutions of the European Union. Of course, the slow recovery has been negatively affected by the economic and financial crisis, undeasured austerity measures, which has had a negative impact on social protection systems, an increase in the number of people suffering from poverty and social exclusion, in particular the increase in the number of children in poverty and increased in-work poverty. So it is not surprising that in some countries people have chosen emigration as a way out. I call on the Member States to implement the Youth Employment Initiative as soon as possible and that more funding for youth employment is needed in the review of the EU budget. Strong links between education, economic and labour market policies are needed. Only this will bring real results to the citizens of our European Union.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Madam President, the ONLY way for the EU to achieve its employment target of 75% is to strengthen the position of women in the labour market and to reduce the gender employment gap. Although equality between men and women is one of the core values of the European Union, several current research shows that there are still significant differences in the work experience of men and women and in the balance between work and family life. There are a number of reasons for this situation, which vary from country to country, and therefore there cannot be a single European solution. One of the fundamental reasons is the lack of childcare solutions. Most mothers don't work or work part-time either because they either lack childcare services or are too expensive.  Only a few Member States have managed to achieve the pre-school childcare target. Based on their experience, the solutions are: 1. provide childcare facilities that better reflect parents' working hours, 2. provide childcare allowances, 3. amend childcare leave laws, 4. provide for flexible working hours. In order to achieve this, the Commission and the Council would have to focus more on this issue in the European Semester.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As you know, Member States are moving away from the EU 2020 targets rather than moving closer to them. The injustice in distribution is huge. We have 25 million unemployed, one in four are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. This is, of course, a consequence of the crisis, but above all a consequence of the wrong policy, the policy of saving money. It is therefore incomprehensible to me why, in the context of the European Semester, there is not much more attention paid to and work towards the EU 2020 objectives. The crucial point is that aspects in the areas of employment and social affairs must be dealt with in a binding and equal footing with economic criteria. You, Commissioner, are now called upon, you and, of course, the Commission's colleagues. A lot of work awaits you, including the investment plan that we expect from the President of the Commission... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Georges BACH
text: Madam President! After five years of the Europe 2020 strategy, it is time to make an assessment and learn from the mistakes of the first few years. It cannot be overlooked that, especially in the area of social policy, we are still a long way from achieving the objectives that have been set. To be sure, the Member States are responsible for their respective social and employment-related systems. In principle, I also agree with this division of powers. However, it is becoming increasingly clear that the Member States are not acting quickly and effectively enough, and in some cases very stubbornly. This is quite clear, for example, in the Youth Guarantee or other initiatives for youth employment. The fact is that it is essential that the social indicators are strengthened and perhaps become binding if we are to achieve the objectives of the strategy in the first place. Another issue that is particularly close to my heart is poverty and the ever-increasing risk of falling into poverty. We must not fight poverty with precarious jobs, but we must find long-term solutions. For this reason, it is essential to promote growth. I look forward to the presentation by Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker tomorrow morning and eagerly await his proposals on the Investment Pact, in the hope that the employment and social aspects of the Europe 2020 strategy will be strengthened and promoted.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Madam President, the results of the 2020 strategy are disappointing and especially in terms of achieving social objectives, because for four years we have been going from bad to worse. Even the European Semester as a tool is proving inadequate and ineffective. From a country I know best, the five social and labour indicators are as follows: unemployment of 30%; youth unemployment 60%; citizens at risk of falling below the 30% poverty line; citizens already below the 20% poverty line. The inequalities are dramatic. 20% of the highest income earners receive six times as much as 20% of those with the lowest income. The countries of the South most at risk are those which are excluded from European economic governance. The Commission remains in the process of responding without responding to ways of activating mechanisms that can address the problems. The Lux Leaks scandal shows that countries that are forced to have high taxes are being subjected to an outflow of money... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Credit to Marita Ulvskog for her report. (Marita, very good job!) You have made it very clear that development should be smart – not sustainable – and not inclusive – nor is it. What we are seeing, on the other hand, is increasing regional contrasts within the European Union as well. The cost of living is being evened out, at the same time aspirations to live to a higher standard are widening, and income disparities are widening. Junk contracts are the first factor, the second is differences in quality of life, which, moreover, result in increasing emigration, e.g. from Polish, Romania, Greece, etc. The fact is that labour productivity is growing much faster than wages. Hence, I join the appeal on youth work, but let us not forget the 55+ generation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: If we are to kick-start employment, we need to invest in projects with high added value. In many Member States, more than 80% of public investment exists simply because it is financed by the European budget.  The Europe 2020 strategy is intended to help us create new, quality jobs, improve quality of life, reduce poverty and social exclusion. Paradoxically, on the one hand, we know which way to achieve our objectives, on the other hand, the Council is struggling to finance what it has itself approved. She is not even able to submit a repayment schedule for us, when she will pay invoices for projects already implemented. This problem is growing like a snowball for the fifth year. If the Council is to be honest, if it wants employment and smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, it must abide by the rules on economic governance and budgetary discipline and fulfil what it commits to.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your cooperation in catching up with us in order to stay on time.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. - There is currently a reflection in the Commission on whether and how the 2020 strategy and the European semester can be improved. The time is right! I think this debate has shown this. You can count on me and the Commission. We assume that the strategies must serve the people, that we must ensure better results in order to meet people's expectations, if we want to regain people's trust. There are a lot of success factors mentioned here, factors that we can and must work with to do better, and ultimately they all come down to the fact that we need to increase investment. I am therefore pleased that tomorrow we will hear from President Juncker what the investment plan he has developed will look like, because ultimately it will be about more investment for more growth, for quality jobs. I will continue to work to ensure that employment and social considerations are properly and better placed in the European economic governance framework, and I think that also responds to what Members of this Parliament are asking for and expecting. The strategy is therefore now being evaluated as has been said. In the spring, the Commission will come up with the conclusions and proposals. This debate will certainly inspire us to go in the right direction and I would like to thank you very much for your attention.  I am sorry that I cannot respond to all the questions of all my colleagues, but as you have heard, the time is too short. Thanks for your input, we take it into account.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say to the Members who have spoken that your concerns are ours. You have said that, of course, the ball is much more in the Council's court and this time we want to play it much better.  The key point you have raised is the fight against social inequalities. This is a key point, which is why we certainly believe that the Social Fund and the Structural Funds must increasingly be the real financial pillars of this new social dimension that we want to develop in the Europe 2020 strategy. A strategy that the Presidency also wants greener, greener. That is something you have raised. I would remind you that we have opened our Presidency by bringing together, for the first time, the Ministers for the Environment and the Ministers for Labour, because we believe that green jobs, green jobs, are what has been lacking so far in the Europe 2020 strategy and we are convinced that by integrating these processes much more we will have more effectiveness and we will be able to achieve better results that we can be much more satisfied with than we are today in the light of what we are in the light of. we couldn't do it.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I have received, in accordance with Article 115, paragraph 1, a motion for a resolution from the regulation.  The debate is closed. The vote will take place today from 12 p.m. (The meeting is suspended at 11 a.m. pending the formal sitting.)  Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: in writing.– As part of the EU2020 strategy, we have committed to helping at least 75% of all Europeans aged between 20 and 64 into a job by 2020, to reduce the number of early school leavers to below 10%, and to remove at least 20 million Europeans from poverty. We must ensure that we achieve these objectives effectively.  We can do this by focusing much more on our young people, by ensuring that they can get started. This can be done, among other things, by means of the Youth Guarantee Plan, but also by setting specific targets for youth employment as part of the review of the EU2020 strategy. The investment programme to combat unemployment, announced by President Juncker, can play an important role in preserving and creating jobs.  We must also put more resources into the fight against poverty. Today, around 1 in 4 EU citizens are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. We cannot stand by passively and accept this. We have to give people opportunities, give them a future.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Written. The Convention, as well as the speech by the four Presidents, did not take social union into account. It is only thanks to Parliament's intervention that this issue has once again been on the European agenda. I call on the Commission and the Council, represented here by the Presidency, to speed up every measure and instrument for creating jobs, in particular to respond to the scourge of youth unemployment, and for Europe to complete its integration at the level of the Treaties too, becoming a genuine social union.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – The challenges faced by decision-makers in the Member States of the Union in the field of social affairs and employment have diversified and are constantly diversifying. As such, initial strategies for these areas, focusing on reducing unemployment in the medium and long term, need to be adapted on the go to take account of all emerging new factors, as well as the ageing of the population, in order to limit its negative effects. In addition, workers and companies in all EU countries are under pressure for the need to adapt as quickly as possible to changes caused by technological progress and the effects of globalisation. To do this, the EU needs to provide the economic resources needed to invest in education, health and other forms of human resources development, because without well-trained workers, Europe cannot have the trajectory of the economic development it wants.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. – The message of the European Parliament to the Member States is clear in this resolution. In order to reach 75% employment targets of the EU 2020 strategy and to fight youth unemployment, we need to focus on structural reforms aiming to eliminate unnecessary administrative burden and bureaucracy for the self-employed, micro-enterprises and SMEs as well as facilitate the conditions for start-up businesses. It is also important to shift the tax burden away from labour to allow job creation and to improve entrepreneurial skills among young people to encourage them to make a difference to their lives.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – Despite the principles of solidarity and equality between Member States and EU efforts, there are still regions where the population is progressively impoverished. The poorest region in the EU is Northwestern Bulgaria, which faces severe demographic catastrophe, progressive population decline, ageing, high levels of unemployment, low economic activity and prospect, extremely high levels of migration – to other regions of Bulgaria and outside the country. To address these negative economic and demographic trends, an EU-level mechanism for direct investment in these areas in the fields of education, employment promotion, financial support for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone of the economy in similar regions, should be adopted.  Bulgaria needs a similar mechanism to focus on regional stimulation, because in the past 25 years 2 million people have immigrated from the country. People. Moreover, the Bulgarian population is progressively declining because in some regions there is no economic prospect and people are fleeing from there, which raises the question of the disintegration of these regions from the more developed and economically stable ones. The Commission and Parliament should take into account that a new, more active, more flexible and stable approach to the poorest areas is needed because they are disadvantaged compared to more developed regions where investment and policies focus – national and European.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: In writing – I agree with the questioner that since the onset of the financial and economic crisis, the number of citizens exposed to unemployment and poverty has increased significantly. In order to reduce unemployment, we must use all the tools that we have in each EU policy. By 2050, we need to increase food production in the world by 70% so that we can food all our fellow human beings. The European Union has the right natural and economic resources to lead this process. Sustainable farming methods and responsible use of resources can also be used to increase production. Agriculture and related industries, such as timber production and furniture, or energy production from biomass and biogas, can create a number of permanent and seasonal jobs. We must therefore seize all means to support agriculture. On the one hand, Union aid, in particular direct aid, should be kept at a level. On the other hand, the unjustified financial and administrative burden on farmers and businesses must be reduced. New unjustified animal welfare, food safety or environmental restrictions, such as the increase of ecological importance, should not be imposed. Thirdly, the EU must protect European farmers from dumping agricultural goods from third countries. Free trade agreements should be signed that do not result in a loss of competitiveness for European farmers.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - Strategy 2020 and the period up to 2020 will be crucial for the further political future of the European Union. Successful economic development and positive social growth can only convincingly ensure the political recognition of the European Union.  Today, 120 million Europeans are at the poverty line and 16 million are unemployed. If the next five years do not take advantage of all significant investments in large, but especially in small and medium-sized enterprises, there will be no success of European policy. A person without a secure income is rightly distrustful of any authority. We know that many EU countries today can practically only boost their development through world European development.  Croatia is the only one of the countries in such a situation. A particularly vulnerable group is the multi-year youth unemployment and still the inequality of women's position in the labour market. That is why the 2020 Strategy will be a recognizable success this term only if it manages to satisfy all interests.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Europe 2020 strategy lists an increase in m.in employment rate to 75% among its objectives. Achieving this goal will be difficult, as the value of this indicator has been hovering around 69% for several years, showing very weak upward trends. It consists of a 75% employment rate for men and a 63% employment rate for women. There is therefore a 12% employment gap between women and men, which in some Member States reaches 30% and is responsible for the 40% gap in the pensions of women and men in Europe and the poverty of older women. Closing the employment gap, increasing women's participation in the labour market is an effective path not only to rapid economic growth, but also to greater social justice in Europe. Recent years have shown that employment growth in the Member States is mainly achieved through an increase in women's employment and that the key to this process is the implementation of the principle of gender equality. Women are statistically better educated and motivated to work than men – but in the end, the barriers that block their access to the market must be removed. The demands for gender equality need to be implemented more effectively. Crèches, kindergartens, nursing homes, equal sharing of responsibilities for unpaid homework, closing the square gap are the conditions necessary to increase the presence of women on the market and thus to europe's smart and sustainable economic growth.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: Written. – The statistics available to us are alarming: various indicators show that there are almost 25 million unemployed in the EU and unemployment at 10%. There is a need to focus on reducing poverty and creating jobs. It is also important to close the gap between Member States, especially in regions that are far from the European average and standard. It is therefore in our interest to promote the Single Market, sustainable and inclusive growth and to focus on creating new jobs. Although youth unemployment is a serious problem for the EU, I also believe that we must not forget the older members of our society. Demographic change and an ageing population will directly affect the EU's social and economic model. They must therefore not surprise us.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: Written. – With this motion for a resolution, the European Parliament expresses very clearly to the European Commission and the Council that European policies must focus on people. Financial and economic priorities must be addressed by social priorities, which in itself justifies the relevance of this resolution. I am pleased that a standard is introduced that addresses the diversity of opportunities in the Whole of Europe, integrating the plurality of European realities. I am referring to the consideration of the specificnature of the outermost regions, in particular the view that they are facing increased inequalities in access to employment and training opportunities, and that the ORs require specific enhanced mechanisms for the implementation of investment programmes in order to achieve the objectives of the 2020 Strategy and to promote their potential for economic and social development.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – All my fellow Members agree that one of Europe's greatest tasks and duties is to eradicate youth unemployment completely as soon as possible. More than five million young people are out of work in the EU, more than 27% in Hungary. One of the most pressing problems in the newly acceded countries, including my own country, is also linked to youth unemployment: economic emigration due to lack of prospects. Nearly half a million young people in Hungary have already decided to emigrate. Mass emigration causes not only emotional but also social and economic difficulties. And what you may not see and understand in Western Europe: not just the countries concerned. According to the latest statement from the Institute for the Future of Work research in Bonn, five million citizens of the Eastern Central and Eastern European countries that have joined the EU since 2004 currently live in western EU countries. According to the researchers, this process can adversely affect the health and quality of life of the hungarian population. One of the important values of the European community is the free movement of labour, which must be preserved. But we cannot allow Europe to allow some of its countries to kneel because of the economic forced emigration of their own citizens. That is why, as a Social Democrat MEMBER, I have launched the Hazaváró programme in Hungary and I call on the European community to expand it. We need to find a common solution, because this is a common problem for Europe.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. In order to achieve the objectives and priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy, it is necessary to urgently review the entire economic governance designed in response to the crisis.  With more than 24 million unemployed and one in four citizens at risk of poverty, growth cannot be revived by focusing on budgetary objectives.  The dramatic results of austerity policies, combined with the ineffectiveness of monetary policy, indicate that the only possible way out of the crisis and reviving growth is to allow states to implement expansionary fiscal policies, which stimulate domestic demand, without those absurd and unfounded constraints, which especially in times of recession have perverse and counterproductive effects.  Rather, the EU will be able to make a difference if it is able to give concrete support to The Member States, for example by ensuring the efficient spending of the Structural Funds, as well as by adopting direct support measures for demand and citizens. One of the most effective measures in this regard would undoubtedly be the income of European citizenship, in order to prevent more and more citizens from being reduced to poverty by the economic crisis and excluded from society.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: Written. – The EU 2020 strategy has ambitious social objectives. However, its implementation has not been systemic. Nominal Europe has subjugated real Europe. Financial indicators, not people, have been the benchmark for policies. The timing of the intermediate evaluation of the Strategy is approaching. In many countries, key indicators such as employment or poverty have regressed rather than progressed. Inequalities increase rather than reduce. An ambitious review of the Strategy is therefore necessary. Jean-Claude Juncker has pledged to breathe new life into the Union's social policies. Matteo Renzi, President-in-Office of the Council, said that flexibility is the proper thing of politics while the crystallization of norms is proper to technocracy. 25 million unemployed Europeans demand a reinvention of the European economic model. A reinvention focused on the dignity and happiness of Europeans.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Your Holiness Pope Francis, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen! Twenty-six years ago, Pope John Paul II addressed the European Parliament. His speech was a milestone on the road to the fall of the Iron Curtain and the beginning of the reunification of Europe. Today, Pope Francis, you are speaking to a European Parliament whose members represent more than 500 million people from 28 Member States. Members of this House represent the diversity of Europe. Over the past six years, Europe has experienced a dramatic and unprecedented crisis. This crisis has serious consequences. The loss of trust in people in their institutions, at national and also at European level, is particularly dramatic. This loss of confidence is enormous. Without trust, however, no idea, let alone an institution, can survive permanently. That is why the cooperation of all forces is necessary in order to regain the lost trust. In this respect, the concerns of the European Union and its institutions and those of the Catholic Church go hand in hand to a large extent. The values of tolerance, respect, equality, solidarity and peace are part of our common mission. The European Union stands for each other rather than against each other, for inclusion rather than exclusion. Young people are struggling to find work and their place in our society, migrants are looking for a better future for themselves and their children, people are fleeing wars and disasters and are seeking asylum and protection here. Whether it is the issue of social justice or the unequal distribution of wealth and life chances, whether it is about the situation of old people in our society, or whether it is about wars and conflicts in our neighbourhood and beyond, we face common challenges. Your holiness, your words have enormous significance. Not only because you are the religious leader of more than a billion Catholics. Your words are extremely important because they concern us all, because they are also addressed to all of us and are valid for all of us, because the issues you raise affect us all and concern us all. These themes are universal. Her words provide orientation in times of disorientation. Their messages of peace and dialogue, sincerity and responsibility for each other, solidarity and coexistence clearly show us that we must solve common tasks together, that we are stronger together than alone. Their message is a very European message. It is precisely on this message that the idea of European unification is based. And your history, your holiness, is a European story. The story of a family that has left Europe and found a new home in South America. It is the story of a pope who returns from the other side of the Atlantic, from the other side of the world, to reform his Church and lead the faithful. It is a story that can serve as a model for us and help Europe to renew and reform itself. I thank you, on behalf of all my fellow Members, for being with us today and for accepting and following the invitation of the European Parliament. It is an honour and a privilege for this House to be able to listen to you today. Your Holiness Pope Francis, you have the floor. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, people who work in different titles in this Chamber, dear friends, I thank you for your invitation to speak before this fundamental institution of the life of the European Union and for the opportunity you give me, through you, to address the more than five hundred million citizens you represent in the 28 Member States. I would like to express my particular gratitude to you, Mr President of Parliament, for the warm words of welcome you have addressed to me on behalf of all members of this House. My visit comes more than a quarter of a century after that made by Pope John Paul II. Much has changed since those days in Europe and around the world. There are no longer the opposing blocs which then divided the continent in two, and the desire is slowly being made that 'Europe, by sovereignly giving itself free institutions, can one day extend to the dimensions given to it by geography and even more by history'. Alongside a wider European Union, there is also a more complex and highly moving world. An increasingly interconnected and global world and therefore less and less "Eurocentric". A larger, more influential Union, however, seems to be accompanied by the image of a Europe that is somewhat aged and compressed, which tends to feel less protagonist in a context that often looks at it with detachment, mistrust and sometimes with suspicion.  In addressing you today, starting from my vocation as pastor, I would like to send a message of hope and encouragement to all European citizens. A message of hope based on the confidence that difficulties can become powerful engines of unity, in order to overcome all the fears that Europe - together with the whole world - is going through. Hope in the Lord who transforms evil into good and death into life.  Encouragement to return to the firm conviction of the founding fathers of the European Union, who wanted a future based on the ability to work together to overcome divisions and to foster peace and communion among all the peoples of the continent. At the heart of this ambitious political project was trust in man, not so much as a citizen, nor as an economic entity, but in man as a person with transcendent dignity. First of all, I would like to stress the close link that exists between these two words: 'dignity' and 'transcendent'.  "Dignity" is the key word that characterized the recovery of the second post-war period. Our recent history is characterized by the undoubted centrality of the promotion of human dignity against the multiple violence and discriminations that have not been lacking in Europe over the centuries either. The perception of the importance of human rights arises precisely as the result of a long journey, also made up of multiple sufferings and sacrifices, which has helped to form the awareness of the preciousness, uniqueness and unrepeability of every single human person. This cultural awareness is based not only in the events of history, but above all in European thought, characterized by a rich encounter, whose many distant sources come "from Greece and Rome, from Celtic, Germanic and Slavic substrates, and from Christianity that has shaped them deeply", giving rise precisely to the concept of "person". Today, the promotion of human rights plays a central role in the European Union's commitment to promoting the dignity of the individual, both internally and in relations with other countries. This is an important and admirable commitment, because there are still far too many situations in which human beings are treated as objects, whose conception, configuration and usefulness can be programmed, and which can then be thrown away when they are no longer needed, because they have become weak, sick or old. Indeed, what dignity exists when there is no possibility of freely expressing one's thoughts or of professing one's religious faith without constraint? What dignity is possible without a clear legal framework that limits the domination of force and makes the law prevail over the tyranny of power? What dignity can a man or a woman ever have, the subject of all kinds of discrimination? What dignity can a person who does not have the food or the bare minimum for living find and, worse still, who has nothing but the work of dignity?  Promoting the dignity of the person means recognising that he has inalienable rights of which he cannot be deprived of any arbitrariness, let alone for the benefit of economic interests.  However, care must be taken not to fall into some misunderstandings that may arise from a misunderstanding of the concept of human rights and their paradoxical abuse. In fact, there is now a tendency towards an ever-increasing demand for individualism – I am tempted to say individualistic – which conceals a conception of a human person detached from every social and anthropological context, almost as a "monad" (μονάς), increasingly insensitive to the other "monads" around him. The concept of law no longer seems to be associated with the equally essential and complementary concept of duty, so that we end up affirming the rights of the individual without taking into account that every human being is linked to a social context, in which his rights and duties are linked to those of others and to the common good of society itself. I therefore believe that it is very vital today to deepen a culture of human rights that can skilfully link the individual, or rather, personal dimension, to that of the common good, to that "we-all" formed by individuals, families and intermediate groups that unite in a social community. In fact, if everyone's right is not harmoniously ordained to the greatest good, it ends up conceiving itself without limitations and therefore becoming a source of conflict and violence.  To speak of the transcendent dignity of man, therefore, means to appeal to his nature, to his innate ability to distinguish good from evil, to that "compass" inscribed in our hearts and which God has imprinted in the created universe; above all it means looking at man not as an absolute, but as a relational being. One of the diseases that I see most prevalent in Europe today is loneliness, which is the very loneliness of those without links. It is particularly evident in the elderly, often left to their fate, as well as in young people without reference points and opportunities for the future; you can see it in the many poor people who populate our cities; you can see it in the lost eyes of the migrants who came here in search of a better future.  This loneliness was then exacerbated by the economic crisis, the effects of which still persist with dramatic social consequences. It can also be seen that, in recent years, alongside the process of enlarging the European Union, public mistrust of institutions considered distant, committed to establishing rules perceived as far removed from the sensitivity of individual peoples, or even harmful, has increased. In many quarters we get a general impression of tiredness and ageing, of a europe that is a grandmother and no longer fertile and lively. So the great ideals that inspired Europe seem to have lost its attractiveness, in favour of the bureaucratic technicality of its institutions.  This is associated with somewhat selfish lifestyles, characterized by an opulence now unsustainable and often indifferent to the surrounding world, especially the poorest. It is regrettable that technical and economic issues prevail at the heart of the political debate, to the detriment of a genuine anthropological orientation. The human being is in danger of being reduced to a mere cog in a mechanism that treats it as a consumer good to be used, so that – as we often note – when life is not functional to this mechanism it is discarded without much hesitation, as in the case of the sick, the terminally ill, the abandoned and careless elderly, or children killed before they are born.  It is the great misunderstanding that occurs 'when the absolutization of technology prevails', which ends up creating 'a confusion between ends and means'. Inevitable result of the "culture of waste" and "exasperated consumerism". On the contrary, affirming the dignity of the person means recognizing the preciousness of human life, which is given to us free of charge and cannot therefore be exchanged or disposed of. You, in your vocation as Parliamentarians, are also called to a great mission, although it may seem pointless: to take care of the fragility of peoples and people. Caring for fragility says strength and tenderness, says struggle and fecundity in the midst of a functionalist and privatist model that leads inexorably to the "culture of waste". Caring for the fragility of people and peoples means preserving memory and hope; it means taking charge of the present in its most marginal and distressing situation and being able to aage it of dignity. How, then, can we restore hope to the future, so that, starting with the younger generations, confidence can be restored in order to pursue the great ideal of a united and peaceful, creative and enterprising Europe, respectful of rights and aware of its duties? To answer this question, let me use an image. One of Raphael's most famous frescoes in the Vatican depicts the so-called School of Athens. At its center are Plato and Aristotle. The first with the finger pointing upwards, towards the world of ideas, we could say to the sky; the second extends his hand forward, towards the one who looks, towards the earth, concrete reality. It seems to me to be an image that well describes Europe and its history, made up of the continuous encounter between heaven and earth, where heaven indicates openness to the transcendent, to God, who has always distinguished European man, and the earth represents his practical and concrete ability to face situations and problems. The future of Europe depends on the rediscovery of the vital and inseparable link between these two elements. A Europe that is no longer able to open itself to the transcendent dimension of life is a Europe that slowly risks losing its soul and also that "humanistic spirit" that it also loves and defends.  Precisely starting from the need for an openness to the transcendent, I intend to affirm the centrality of the human person, otherwise at the mercy of the fashions and powers of the moment. In this sense, I consider fundamental not only the heritage that Christianity has left in the past to the socio-cultural formation of the continent, but above all the contribution it intends to make today and in the future to its growth. This contribution does not constitute a danger to the secularity of the States and to the independence of the Union's institutions, but to enrichment. This is shown by the ideals that formed it from the beginning, such as peace, subsidiarity and mutual solidarity, a humanism focused on respect for the dignity of the person. I would therefore like to renew the readiness of the Holy See and the Catholic Church, through the Commission of European Bishops' Conferences, to have a fruitful, open and transparent dialogue with the institutions of the European Union. Likewise, I am convinced that a Europe that is able to treasure its religious roots, knowing how to grasp its richness and potential, can also be more easily immune from the many extremisms that are rampant in today's world, not least because of the great ideal vacuum we are witnessing in the so-called West, because "it is precisely God's oblivion, and not its glorification, that generates violence".  We cannot fail to mention here the many injustices and persecutions that affect religious, and particularly Christian, minorities in different parts of the world on a daily basis. Communities and persons who find themselves subjected to barbaric violence: driven from their homes and homelands; sold as slaves; killed, beheaded, crucified and burned alive, under the shameful and complicit silence of so many. The Motto of the European Union is 'Unity in Diversity', but unity does not mean political, economic, cultural or thought uniformity. In reality, every authentic unit lives on the richness of the diversity that makes it up: as a family, which is all the more united the more each of its members can be fully self-fearless. In this respect, I believe that Europe is a family of peoples, who will be able to feel close to the institutions of the Union if they are able to skilfully combine the ideal of unity that they yearn for, with the diversity of each one, enhancing individual traditions; becoming aware of its history and roots; freeing himself from the many manipulations and phobias. Putting the human person at the centre means first of all letting it freely express its face and creativity, both at the level of the individual and at the level of the people.  On the other hand, the peculiarities of each one constitute an authentic wealth inso far as they are put at the service of all. We must always remember the european Union's own architecture, based on the principles of solidarity and subsidiarity, so that mutual aid prevails and we can walk, animated by mutual trust. In this dynamic of unity and particularity, you, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, also have the need to take responsibility for keeping alive the democracy of the peoples of Europe. There is no hiding the fact that a homologous conception of the whole world affects the vitality of the democratic system by de-strengthening the rich, fruitful and constructive conflict between political organisations and parties. So you run the risk of living in the realm of idea, of speech alone, of image, of sophisma... and end up confusing the reality of democracy with a new political nominalism. Keeping democracy alive in Europe requires avoiding so many "globalizing ways" of diluting reality: angelic purisms, the totalitarianisms of its kind, atoric fundamentalism, ethicalism without goodness, intellectualism without wisdom. Keeping the reality of democracies alive is a challenge of this historic moment, preventing their real strength – the expressive political force of the peoples – from being removed in the face of pressure from non-universal multinational interests, weakening them and transforming them into uniform systems of financial power in the service of unknown empires. This is a challenge that history presents to you today. Giving hope Europe does not only mean recognising the centrality of the human person, but also promoting its skills. It is therefore a question of investing in it and in the areas in which its talents are formed and bear fruit. The first area is certainly that of education, starting with the family, a fundamental cell and a precious element of every society. The united, fertile and indissoluble family brings with it the fundamental elements to give hope to the future. Without this solidity we end up building on sand, with serious social consequences. On the other hand, emphasizing the importance of the family not only helps to give prospects and hope to the new generations, but also to the many elderly people, often forced to live in conditions of loneliness and abandonment because there is no longer the warmth of a domestic hearth able to accompany and support them. Alongside the family are educational institutions: schools and universities. Education cannot be limited to providing a set of technical knowledge, but must promote the more complex process of growth of the human person as a whole. Today's young people are asking to be able to have adequate and complete training to look to the future with hope, rather than disillusionment. Europe's creative potential in various fields of scientific research is also numerous, some of which have not yet been fully explored. We need only think, for example, of alternative sources of energy, the development of which would greatly benefit the protection of the environment.  Europe has always been at the forefront of a commendable commitment to ecology. In fact, this land of ours needs continuous care and attention and everyone has a personal responsibility to preserve creation, a precious gift that God has put in the hands of men. This means, on the one hand, that nature is at our disposal, we can enjoy it and make good use of it; on the other hand, however, it means that we are not the masters. Keepers, but not masters. We must therefore love and respect it, while "instead we are often guided by the pride of domination, possessing, manipulating, exploiting; we do not "custody" it, we do not respect it, we do not consider it as a free gift to take care of". Respect for the environment, however, means not only avoiding disfiguring it, but also using it for good. I am thinking in particular of the agricultural sector, which is called upon to give support and nourishment to man. It cannot be tolerated that millions of people in the world starve to death, while tonnes of food are discarded from our tables every day. Moreover, respecting nature reminds us that man himself is a fundamental part of it. In addition to an environmental ecology, we therefore need that human ecology, made up of respect for the person, which I wanted to recall today by addressing you. The second area in which the talents of the human person flourish is work. It is time to promote employment policies, but above all it is necessary to restore dignity to work, while also ensuring adequate conditions for its implementation. This implies, on the one hand, finding new ways of combining market flexibility with the need for stability and certainty of job prospects, which are essential for the human development of workers; on the other hand, it means promoting an adequate social context, which is not about the exploitation of people, but about ensuring, through work, the possibility of building a family and educating children.  Similarly, the issue of migration must be tackled together. We cannot allow the Mediterranean Sea to become a great graveyard! On the boats that arrive on European shores on a daily basis, there are men and women who need reception and help. The lack of mutual support within the European Union risks encouraging special solutions to the problem, which do not take into account the human dignity of immigrants, encouraging slave labour and continuing social tensions. Europe will be able to cope with immigration issues if it is able to clearly propose its cultural identity and implement appropriate legislation that can at the same time protect the rights of European citizens and guarantee the reception of migrants; if it is able to adopt correct, courageous and concrete policies that help their countries of origin in socio-political development and in overcoming internal conflicts – the main cause of this phenomenon – instead of the policies of interest that increase and fuel these conflicts. It is necessary to act on the causes and not only on the effects. Mr President, Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, awareness of one's own identity is also necessary in order to engage in a proactive dialogue with the States that have applied to join the Union in the future. I am thinking in particular of those in the Balkan area for whom the in the European Union will be able to respond to the ideal of peace in a region that has suffered greatly from the conflicts of the past. Finally, awareness of one's identity is indispensable in relations with other neighbouring countries, particularly those bordering the Mediterranean, many of which suffer as a result of internal conflicts and the pressure of religious fundamentalism and international terrorism. It is up to you legislators to preserve and grow the European identity, so that citizens can regain confidence in the Union's institutions and in the peace and friendship project that undersoes it. Knowing that "the more the power of men grows, the more their personal and collective responsibility is extended and expanded". I therefore urge you to work to make Europe rediscover its good soul.  An anonymous author of the second century wrote that " Christians represent in the world what the soul is in the body". The task of the soul is to support the body, to be its conscience and historical memory. And a two-thousand-year history links Europe and Christianity. A story not without conflicts and errors, even sins, but always animated by the desire to build for good. We see it in the beauty of our cities, and even more so in that of the many works of charity and common human edification that support the continent. This story, for the most part, is yet to be written. It is our present and also our future. It is our identity. And Europe is in great need of rediscovering its face in order to grow, in the spirit of its founding fathers, in peace and harmony, since it itself is not yet free from conflict. Dear MEPs, the time has come to build together the Europe that revolves not around the economy, but around the sacredness of the human person, of inalienable values; Europe, which boldly embraces its past and looks with confidence to its future in order to live its present fully and with hope. The time has come to abandon the idea of a Europe that is afraid and bent over itself in order to arouse and promote Europe as a protagonist, bearer of science, art, music, human values and even faith. Europe that contemplates heaven and pursues ideals; the Europe that looks at, defends and protects man; europe that walks on the earth safe and firm, a precious point of reference for all humanity! Thank you.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. Your applause has shown that Pope Francis spoke from the heart of many of you, I had the impression that he had all. I would like to say that we are grateful to you. Grateful for this speech, grateful for this great encouragement. I see what you have said as an encouragement to move forward on the path that the European Union, the European Community has taken. This is a path that leads to a bright future if we stand together. They have given us important information. Holy Father, I thank you on behalf of the whole of the European Parliament and repeat what I said at the beginning: yes, you are a personality who gives orientation in times of disorientation. We are infinitely grateful to you for that today. Thank you for coming and speaking to us. Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for giving the Holy Father, with your presence and also with your applause, the support of the European Parliament for the path he is taking. I believe that we have many common tasks in which the words of Pope Francis help us. Once again, thank you very much, Holy Father! (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr. President, colleagues! On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and on the basis of Rule 190(4) of the Rules of Procedure, I would like to request that this resolution be postponed until the December part-session. I would ask the LIBE Committee and the applicants for the committees involved to be able to discuss such far-reaching issues. This is not just a question, it has other implications. An opinion from the European Court of Justice can take up to thirty months. Thus, the time factor in the forward line is already a crucial political issue for many things. That is why, on such an important issue, the committees involved, from LIBE to AFET, and whoever else, should be involved, so that we have a real exchange here on the consequences by the time of the December plenary session. I think that would be a fair trial.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Mr. President! I would like to support the motion. On the one hand, this approach was not so agreed among the shadow rapporteurs. We in the group did not have enough time to discuss the scope and possibilities in detail. And I also think it is appropriate to talk about these effects, because we all need to realise what this actually means for partnerships with other states, for the airlines, but also for our political responsibility. Because we are the legislator and not the European Court of Justice. We must also start taking political responsibility!

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I almost said, 'Oh, they're not sweet!' In recent days, I have always heard from the opponents of the Court's questioning that a case before the ECJ could take perhaps two years. Now it's 30 months. If we discuss another week, it will probably take four years. I would also like to remind you that the Pope has just reminded us that we should accept our own rules and values. I have listened to him, too. Whether it is a vote here in the House or an election result, you may not like either if in doubt. However, we must accept a vote. Yesterday we had a vote which was clear. And we should now decide on this decision, on the resolution.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The request for the vote to be postponed shall be rejected.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because the protocol we are asked to approve is closely linked to the fourth rail package, which deepens the privatisation trend of the railway sector. There is no way I will vote in favour of privatisation of the strategic sectors of the economy, such as rail transport.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. - This document aims in particular to stimulate investment in the eu's rail sector by strengthening the security rights of creditors. This is to be welcomed, as this objective is in line with the objectives of the so-called Fourth Railway Package of the European Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to approve the Railway Protocol. The railway protocol aims to facilitate the financing of rolling stock by creating an extremely strong international guarantee for creditors. This will encourage not only capital investment in the rail sector, but also the creation of a market for the rental of mobile rail equipment in Europe. In addition, the Railway Protocol establishes a register of international interests in relation to rolling stock, which will complement the European vehicle identification number system. I believe that the adoption of the Protocol will promote innovation and investment in the European Union's railways, and will support the transition to greener and more sustainable modes of transport, namely rail transport.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment is part of the desire for full liberalisation of the rail sector, to which I am strongly opposed. Moreover, the ratification of the protocol by the European Union, on behalf of the European Union, is contrary to the idea that I advocate cooperation between sovereign states. Those are two good reasons why I could only vote against the adoption of this convention.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - This proposal is linked to the fourth rail package which encourages more innovation and increased investment in the EU's rail system. I voted in favour of this protocol because it will facilitate the supply of funding for rail rolling stock. This will, in my view, not only encourage capital investment in the railway sector but also contribute to the creation of a genuine market for the rental of mobile equipment in Europe.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the draft Council Decision to adopt the Protocol on Specific Issues of Rail Rolling Stock Elements of the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment Elements adopted in Luxembourg on 23 February 2007 because it relates to the fourth rail package and will enable innovation and investment in EU railways to be encouraged as the main objective of the Protocol to facilitate the financing of high-rail rolling stock creating a strong international guarantee for creditors.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment is closely linked to the 4th railway package, the ultimate aim of which is the total liberalisation of rail, with the social or land-use consequences we know (see, the United Kingdom). Yet here, the United Kingdom will not be part of the protocol, as will Denmark. However, for other countries, the case is quite different since a regional economic integration organization will have the same rights to approve this protocol. Thus, the European Union is allowed to ratify this protocol instead of the Member States still sweeping sovereignty and for these reasons I voted against this convention.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) According to the proposal, the railway protocol aims to facilitate the financing of high-value rolling stock railways by creating a strong international guarantee for creditors. The Commission notes that this should encourage not only investment in the rail sector, but also the creation of a genuine rental market for mobile railway equipment in Europe. As there are still serious doubts as to the actual consequences of the manoeuvre and the real interests at stake, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. - I've put down my voice. In its argument, the Commission has underlined the link with the fourth railway package, which I myself oppose. The Commission also underlines the need for further liberalisation in rail transport. For these reasons, I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the ratification of this Convention as it seeks to streamline and protect the investments of railway rolling stock builders against third-country buyers or credit institutions in order to provide them with greater guarantees of payment. In this way, better regulation and greater legal guarantees are promoted at the international level in a market of importance to Europe as the producer of this type of equipment.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted on this recommendation in support of the Council's decision on the Railways Protocol. The Railway Protocol is in line with European Union law and the Council has therefore made use of the Commission's proposal and has decided not to apply the provisions in areas where EU legislation itself is considered appropriate. The Commission's proposal states that the objective of the Railway Protocol is to facilitate the financing of highly valuable rolling stock by creating an exceptionally strong international guarantee for creditors, whether it is the creditors crediting or the institutions crediting such sales. The Commission stresses that this should encourage not only capital investment in the rail sector, but also the creation of a genuine market for the rental of mobile rail equipment in Europe. This Commission proposal is therefore closely linked to the 4th Railway Package, one of the objectives of which is to promote more innovation and investment in EU railways. The proposal notes that the Rail Protocol is also consistent with the objective of supporting the transition to greener and more sustainable modes of transport, such as rail transport.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this legislative resolution because I believe it is essential to develop rail freight transport in Europe.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. - Article 22 of the Protocol on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment provides: "A regional organisation for economic integration made up of sovereign states with jurisdiction over certain matters governed by this Protocol may also sign, accept and approve this Protocol or join it.  In such a case, the regional economic integration organization will have the same rights and obligations as a contracting state." Without prejudging the technical provisions of this protocol, it is the extension of the ratification perimeter that is problematic. Indeed, it is not acceptable for the European Union to be able to ratify such a convention in place of sovereign states in place, which commits them without their respective agreements.  It should also be recalled that these powers devolved to the European Union are based on its exclusive jurisdiction over certain matters relating to the railway sector and on Article 3 of the FUE Treaty which states that: "The Union has exclusive jurisdiction for the conclusion of an international agreement when this conclusion (...) necessary to enable it to exercise its internal competence." As a staunch opponent of this article from the Lisbon Treaty, I naturally voted against the approval, on behalf of the European Union, of the new protocol.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. I abstained. There remains doubt as to the actual consequences of the effects of the measure and the real interests at stake.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The European Parliament voted in favour of the Council's decision to approve the agreement on the Protocol on specific issues of railway rolling stock to the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment. The Protocol encourages capital investment in the rail sector. This goes hand in hand with the objectives of the fourth rail package, which are to encourage innovation and increase investment in the EU's rail system. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the recommendation on international guarantees on capital movable property, with reference to the important aspects relating to railway rolling stock.  Given that logistics is an essential driver for community progress, the aim of the rail protocol is to facilitate the financing of high-value rail rolling stock through the creation of a particularly strong international guarantee for creditors.  This instrument is, in every hope, intended to promote capital investment in the rail sector and at the same time to promote the establishment of a genuine market for the leasing of capital movable property in Europe. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this recommendation as its aim is to increase investment in the railway infrastructure and hence it will improve interconnectivity in Europe. This recommendation also emphasises the need for a more sustainable and environmentally friendly mode of transport.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I am pleased to have contributed, with my vote in favour, to the adoption of this draft decision. The agreement is now dated, in the sense that the process of this protocol started many years ago, when the global conditions were different, and the Italian conditions were unrecognizable with the eyes of today, but the meaning is all the more valid today: we must encourage as much as possible infrastructure investments that create jobs in the short term and allow greater efficiency of the various factors of production in the long term. I think it is important for the EU to support this principle and I look forward to the implementation of this convention.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - On 12 June 2013, the Commission published a proposal for a Council Decision on the adoption, on behalf of the European Union, of the Luxembourg Protocol on specific issues relating to railway rolling stock, annexed to the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment Materials, adopted in Luxembourg on 23 February 2007. On 20 November 2013 the Council adopted a decision on the adoption, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol and, on 14 April 2014, requested the consent of the European Parliament. I supported this Recommendation establishing a register of international guarantees for railway rolling stock and is complementary to the System of the European Vehicle Identification Number adopted under the Railway Interoperability Directive.  On the other hand, it not only promotes capital investment in the rail sector, but also benefits the creation of a genuine mobile rail equipment market in Europe and also encourages innovation and investment in the EU railways.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft approval, on behalf of the EU, of the Protocol on railway equipment annexed to the Convention on International Guarantees on Capital Goods, adopted in Luxembourg on 23 February 2007. I am in favour of this proposal not only because it is consistent with European legal parameters, but also because I believe it is necessary to facilitate the financing of high-value rail rolling stock by creating a particularly strong international guarantee for creditors, thus allowing creditors' rights to be strengthened in the event of default by the debtor through the creation of an international system allowing creditors to enter guarantees on various categories of movable capital goods and to benefit from the of some rules on the preemption and enforceability of the international guarantees entered allowing you to consult and register the guarantees 24 hours a day via the internet. Furthermore, this proposal is closely linked to the fourth railway package, which, among other objectives, aims to encourage greater innovation and investment in Europe's railways, with the aim of achieving greener and more sustainable means of transport.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of this recommendation as I consider that the Rail Protocol is compatible with EU law and that the choice of legal basis for the proposal is correct. Such an instrument is of benefit to the European rail industry, banks and governments by encouraging capital investment in the rail sector. I support the objective of the Rail Protocol, as it facilitates the financing of high-value railway rolling stock by creating strong international guarantees for the creditors. This should encourage not only capital investment in the rail sector, but also benefit the creation of a veritable lease market for mobile railway equipment throughout Europe.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) The European Parliament is called upon to give its consent to the conclusion of the protocol concerning certain aspects relating to railway rolling stock. The proposal is closely linked to the fourth railway package, which, among other objectives, aims to promote greater innovation and investment in European rail transport. According to the proposal, the aim of the railway protocol is to facilitate the financing of high-value rail rolling stock by creating a particularly strong international guarantee for creditors. The Commission notes that such an instrument should not only promote capital investment in the rail sector, but should also encourage the creation of a genuine market for the leasing of capital movable property in Europe.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because the protocol we are asked to approve is closely linked to the fourth rail package, which deepens the privatisation trend of the railway sector. There is no way I will vote in favour of privatisation of the strategic sectors of the economy, such as rail transport.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – According to the proposal the objective of the Rail Protocol is to facilitate the financing of high-value railway rolling stock by creating a strong international guarantee for creditors. The Commission emphasises that this should encourage not only capital investment in the rail sector, but also benefit the creation of a genuine lease market for mobile railway equipment in Europe. The Rail Protocol creates a register of international interests in railway rolling stock and is complementary to the European Vehicle Identification Numbering system. It enables registration and search 24 hours a day using the Internet. The proposal is thus closely connected to the 4th Railway Package, one of the aims of which is to encourage more innovation and investment in EU railways.  As the proposal points out, the Rail Protocol is also consistent with the objective of supporting the shift to greener and more sustainable mode of transport such as rail transport. After having noted that this Protocol creates guarantees for creditors, benefits the creation of a lease market and sustains a greener mode of transport I have voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved the Protocol on specific issues of rail rolling stock to the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment. I have approved a text that will support the provision of funding for rail rolling stock. Thanks to this protocol, an international guarantee for creditors will be created, which will, in particular, encourage capital investment in the railway sector.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. - The protocol on certain aspects of railway rolling stock annexed to the Convention on International Guarantees on Capital Movable Property has several objectives: to facilitate the financing of high-value rail rolling stock through the creation of a particularly strong international guarantee for creditors, to promote capital investment in the rail sector and to promote the creation of a market for the leasing of capital movable property in Europe. The proposal is also closely linked to the fourth railway package, because it encourages more investment and more innovation in Europe's railways, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the protocol.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The report proposes the strengthening of legal homogeneity in the European Union in defiance of national differences. The mutual recognition of legal decisions is here the stumbling block of this political logic. Firmly opposed to European and institutional integration as currently understood by the European Commission, I voted against this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - We are voting against this proposal because it entitles legal or natural persons to claim damages from "an international system" and not from the competent courts.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The aim of the proposal is to approve the EU's Protocol on specific issues relating to railway rolling stock. The Cape Town Convention establishes a uniform regime for the constitution and effects of an international guarantee. The Convention shall apply where the debtor is situated in a Contracting State and strengthens the rights of creditors if the debtor does not comply with his obligations by establishing an international system of creditors which allows creditors to register guarantees for various categories of movable equipment and benefit from rules on priority and enforceability of guarantees. As the rapporteur points out, the proposal under discussion is closely related to the implementation of the fourth railway package, which includes the objective of further progress towards liberalisation and privatisation in the rail sector.  We follow our group's position in voting against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The convention in question applies in cases where the debtor is established in a Contracting State and protects and strengthens the rights of creditors in justified cases where the debtor does not fulfil his obligations by creating an international system for the registration of securities. The European Union has an important position in the production of rolling stock through a number of undertakings doing business in this area. It is therefore important to provide strong international guarantees for creditors to increase investment in rail transport and, at the last stage, to create a leasing market for mobile railway equipment in Europe.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I shall abstain because the aim of the proposal is to facilitate the financing of high-value rolling stock railways by creating a strong international guarantee for creditors, but, in view of the premises, doubts remain as to the real consequences and interests at stake.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the Convention on International Insurance on Mobile Equipment in matters specific to railway rolling stock because it entitles legal or natural persons to claim compensation from "an international system" and not from the competent courts.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Convention on international interests in mobile equipment on matters specific to railway rolling stock. I do believe that after this Convention comes into force it will be much easier to attract investments into the railway sector. More investments into this area will help to modernise this important industry. The system itself will be more transparent and reliable for the investors.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. – I voted for this report which is fully consistent with the aims of encouraging investment and innovation in Europe’s railways. Railways form a key part of the EU’s infrastructure and are thus an important tool for economic development. At present key aspects of my own country’s rail policy are controlled from London where matters of Scottish concern are a low priority. It is essential that the Scottish parliament gains full control over Scotland’s railways so that we can encourage proper development in line with our EU partners.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for a draft legislative resolution related to the Council's draft decision to approve the Protocol to the Convention on International Interests for Mobile Equipment on rolling stock-specific issues, as this facilitates the financing of high-value rolling stock and creates a strong international guarantee for creditors.
