I believe that it is necessary to turn to investment and innovation in the European railways sector, to promote environmental and sustainable modes of transport, and I also support capital investments in the railway sector - especially in some EU countries that show significant backlogs in rail infrastructures.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Heidi Hautala's recommendation on the Protocol on specific issues of railway rolling stock to the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment. This text supports the Council's conclusions in the Ratification by the European Union of the Luxembourg Protocol signed in 2007, which sets international standards for the railway sector. The recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the report on the approval of the Luxembourg Protocol on specific issues of railway rolling stock to the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment. This protocol aims to facilitate the offer of financing for high-value rail rolling stock by creating a strong international guarantee for creditors. It also establishes a unique international registration system for international guarantees and thus participates in the establishment of a common judicial area based on the principle of mutual recognition of judicial decisions, which will encourage capital investment in the railway sector.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. – The Protocol to the Convention makes a useful contribution to the regulation at international level in its area. It is therefore desirable that the provisions of that instrument which concern matters falling within the exclusive competence of the Union be applied as soon as possible.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Heidi Hautala because I believe it is necessary to support this report, which supports the adoption of the protocol on certain aspects of railway rolling stock; This protocol, I am sure, will make the financing of high-value rail rolling stock less complex.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: in writing. – Creating one European Railway Space is important to our economy. Still, there are too many technical and administrative differences between the railways in Europe – not mentioning the infrastructure bottlenecks we face at border crossings – such as between Germany and Poland. Technical issues like different mobile equipment used by the railways in Europe, such as PKK or SNCF in France, create difficulties for locomotives to change from one ‘national’ railway system to the other. Therefore I fully supported this convention and voted in favour. In order to create one European Railway Space we need to have the same technical standards for all of the European railways.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - This concerns the ratification of those parts of the Convention on International Guarantees in relation to rolling stock in which the Union has exclusive competence. This Convention seeks to be able to streamline and protect the investments of railway rolling stock builders against buyers or credit institutions from third countries in order to give them greater guarantees for their effective payment. Europe is a producer of this type of equipment and, in this sense, it is interesting to promote international rules that facilitate an international market for such goods with all legal guarantees.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because the protocol we are asked to approve is closely linked to the fourth rail package, which deepens the privatisation trend of the railway sector. There is no way I will vote in favour of privatisation of the strategic sectors of the economy, such as rail transport.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on authorisation, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol to the Convention on International Interests for Mobile Equipment concerning rolling stock-specific matters, adopted in Luxembourg on 23 February 2007.  The Convention applies where the debtor is located in the Signatory State of the Convention and strengthens the rights of creditors in the event that the debtor fails to repay his obligations through the establishment of an international system for lenders where they register their interests through different categories.  This Protocol facilitates financing while strengthening trust among potential creditors and thus fosters a higher level of capital investment in the railway sector. The Protocol also encourages the transition to a more environmentally conscious and sustainable mode of transport such as rail transport.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because the motorways are what unites the European Union and flush out the obstacles to the single economy. That was also the position of our group.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting against this Recommendation because it legitimises in practice the various memorial policies implemented in relation to railway rolling stock in Greece.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Resolution. According to the proposal the objective of the Rail Protocol is to facilitate the financing of high-value railway rolling stock by creating a strong international guarantee for creditors, whether these are sellers on credit or institutions supplying credit for such sales. The Commission emphasises that this should not only encourage capital investment in the rail sector, but also benefit the creation of a genuine lease market for mobile railway equipment in Europe.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) According to the Convention's proposal on international guarantees on capital movable property, the aim of the railway protocol is to facilitate and promote capital investment in the rail sector and at the same time to promote the establishment of a genuine market for the leasing of capital movable property in Europe. This proposal encourages more investment and more innovation in Europe's railways, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the protocol.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. - The two documents to be accessed by the EU, as requested by the Council, contain some positive elements, such as the effort to protect creditors vis-à-vis debtors who fail to fulfil their obligations by setting up an international system allowing creditors to register rights in rem for different categories of mobile equipment objects and to benefit from rules on the enforceability of such registered claims. The Railway Protocol establishes a register of international entitlements applicable to railway rolling stock. Allows you to register and search 24 hours a day using the Internet. However, behind these noble proposals is the Commission's efforts to encourage capital investment in the rail sector and to create a real market for mobile rail equipment rentals in Europe, in other words the liberalisation and privatisation of the rail sector, as evidenced by the fact that the documents refer to the fourth railway package.  On the basis of my own experience, I know that privatisation in this sector does not bring the expected improvements, but, on the contrary, leads to non-transparent tenders, cancellations of services, neglect of maintenance and repair of means of transport, the technical condition of which depends on the safety of passengers, the dismissal of employees and the overall bankruptcy of the services provided.  Since I am not in favour of such a development, I voted against today.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) I felt it necessary to support mrs Hautala's report, which supports the approval of the Protocol on certain aspects of railway rolling stock, because I believe that it makes the financing of high-value railway rolling stock less complex by creating an international guarantee for creditors.  Such an instrument not only facilitates financial investment, but also the development of a market for the leasing of capital goods in Europe.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since the Convention on International Security Rights in Mobile Equipment for Rolling Railway Equipment would confer further powers on the national supervisory authorities on the Union, it must be rejected. The national monitoring bodies in the financing sector are more familiar with the circumstances of their contracting partner's country than a single European organisation could be.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - It is a question of approving the Council's proposal on the establishment of a railway protocol in relation to the 4th railway package, which I had fought against.  This protocol aims to facilitate the offer of financing for high-value rail rolling stock by creating a strong international guarantee for creditors. The Commission stresses that this protocol should encourage capital investment in the rail sector and contribute to the creation of a private market for the rental of mobile equipment in Europe. The aim is to increase competition at the expense of the public service. Everything I condemn. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the adoption, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol on specific issues relating to railway rolling stock. Several rules of the Railway Protocol allow the Contracting Parties to make statements as to the applicability or scope of its provisions, or even how they will be applied. The Railway Protocol advocates the transition to greener and more sustainable modes of transport, such as rail transport, an objective highlighted in the 2011 White Paper on Transport.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – This recommendation encourages the financing of high-value railway rolling stock, which will incite investment in the rail sector. This strategy will also include a shift towards a more sustainable and environmental friendly mode of transport. I have therefore voted in favour of this recommendation, which will facilitate the growth of railway infrastructure.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The Convention, including its protocols, tends to address the problem of establishing safe and easily executed rights, relating to goods which, by their very nature (e.g. railway rolling stock), do not have a fixed situation. The Protocol, by offering a better international guarantee to creditors investing in the railway sector - notably by completing the European vehicle registration number system and by allowing 24-hour registration and research - will eventually create a genuine market for leasing mobile equipment in Europe.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I supported the Report on the Convention on International Interests in Mobile Equipment on matters specific to Railway Rolling Stock, because adhering to an international convention will provide strong international legal guarantees to creditors in relation with debtors in third countries, which is an important safeguard for EU producers and sellers.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against this Convention, which further transfers our national sovereignty to the European Union. Article 22 of the Protocol on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment stipulates that "a regional organisation of economic integration made up of sovereign states and with jurisdiction over certain matters governed by this protocol may also sign, accept and approve this protocol or adhere to it. In such a case, the regional economic integration organization will have the same rights and obligations as a contracting state." The extension of the ratification perimeter is problematic here since it allows the European Union to ratify, instead of sovereign states, the Convention that will engage them, obviously without respective agreement. It should also be noted that Article 3 of the TFUE (Lisbon Treaty), which provides that "the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction to conclude an international agreement when this conclusion [...] necessary to enable it to exercise its internal competence" has given the European Union exclusive jurisdiction over rail matters.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I supported this report which provides for the ratification by the European Union of the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment. The Convention applies when the debtor is located in a contracting state and strengthens the rights of creditors if the debtor does not perform his obligations. The implementation of this agreement is likely to strengthen investor confidence in the field of mobile equipment.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome Parliament's vote in favour of the draft Council decision approving, on behalf of the European Union, the protocol on certain aspects relating to railway rolling stock annexed to the Convention on International Guarantees on Movable Capital Goods (so-called 'railway protocol'), because I believe that the objectives it has pursued deserve our support. According to the proposal, the aim of the railway protocol is to facilitate the financing of high-value rail rolling stock by creating a particularly strong international guarantee for creditors (credit sellers or financial institutions that have financed such sales). In particular, this instrument should not only promote capital investment in the rail sector, but should also encourage the creation of a genuine market for the leasing of capital movable property in Europe. The proposal is also closely linked to the fourth railway package, which, among other objectives, aims to encourage greater innovation and investment in Europe's railways. Finally, the rail protocol is also in line with the objective, set out in the 2011 Transport White Paper, of moving to greener and more sustainable modes of transport, such as rail transport.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — (DE) There were two main reasons which influenced my vote in the specific case: on the one hand, the Convention on International Security Rights in Mobile Equipment for Rolling Equipment is intended to transfer to the Union the further powers of the national supervisory authorities, which I strongly disagree with. On the other hand, the national monitoring bodies are much closer to the subject matter and to the circumstances much better than a single European organisation could be. That is why I voted against the agreement.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on this report, because although it relates to a Protocol to the Convention on International Interests in Mobile Railway Equipment providing better guarantees and facilities for the purchase of this equipment, which could develop a key sector of European transport, this protocol nevertheless goes in the direction of liberalisation and deregulation of the European rail sector , liberalisation which will lead to more inconvenience for companies in the sector as well as for passengers, as previous rail packages have only led to a gradual increase in train costs for passengers and the disengagement of train companies on certain routes.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because it encourages innovation in the Rail sector in the European Union and increases investment in railways. In addition, it will give creditors stronger international confidence and support the move towards greener transport.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation, which proposes to support the adoption of the Protocol, which benefits the European rail industry, banks and governments. I believe that a strong international guarantee would facilitate the financing of very valuable rolling stock for creditors. Uniform rules on international interest will enable creditors to obtain an international guarantee. They will therefore be given absolute priority over these assets in the international register.  It should be noted that this Protocol also establishes an international system for recording unique and stable international interests and an additional and support european vehicle identification number system.  It should be noted that the Protocol will benefit not only operators but also the public. In addition, capital investment in the rail sector will be encouraged and will contribute to the creation of a genuine rental market.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - Considering that on 12 June 2013 the Commission published a proposal for a Council decision approving, on behalf of the European Union, the Protocol on certain aspects relating to railway rolling stock, given that on 20 November 2013 the Council adopted a decision approving, on behalf of the European Union, that protocol and that on 14 April 2014 it requested the approval of the European Parliament , given that the railway protocol is compatible with EU law, given that the Council has accepted the Commission's proposal, deciding not to opt for the application of the provisions on matters for which EU legislation can be considered appropriate, for these reasons I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — This convention favours the supranational and regional levels at the expense of states and was conceived in the context of privatization and openness of rail transport to competition. Considering that the establishment of a common judicial area is at the expense of the sovereignty of the peoples, I vote against this convention.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I supported peer Heidi Hautale's initiative to recommend a draft Council decision on the approval of the Protocol to the Convention on International Interests in Mobile Equipment on rolling stock-specific matters. With the establishment of the European Railway Agency, the Commission authorised the Agency to develop and revise technical specifications and interoperability, all with a view to extending their scope to the entire European Union without technical, regulatory or operational constraints.  The Agency was asked to develop the interoperability of the subsystem of rolling stock – freight wagons. Common single market standards are not only easier to revise, but reduce costs many times, and the single rail network along the European Union provides faster, cheaper and better quality delivery of goods and facilitates travel for European citizens.  As transport is a shared competence between the European Commission and a Member State, the Commission has created a framework under which decisions and standards must be respected when investing in rail transport. In this win-win situation, Member States only have to keep up with standards to overcome possible barriers to the transport of goods, thereby reducing costs and increasing the competitiveness of their geostrategic position.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the protocol on certain aspects of railway rolling stock because I believe that its adoption will achieve the aim of making the financing of high-value rail rolling stock more accessible by creating an international guarantee for creditors. In this way, investment in the rail sector should increase and, at the same time, a genuine market for the leasing of capital movable property would be created.  If we look at the fourth railway package, which is under discussion at this time, we see that there is a close link with this proposal, where more investment and more innovation are required, with more environmentally friendly and sustainable modes of transport, in the European rail system. With the adoption of the Protocol, where Member States delegate competence to the EU on the matters mentioned in it, a register of international guarantees on capital movable property will be established and the European vehicle numbering system will be integrated under the Railway Interoperability Directive.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Through this recommendation, a favourable vote by the European Parliament helps to promote exchanges on mobile equipment. In other words, the aim of this protocol is to increase guarantees for investment and trade in the rail and automotive sector. I the european Parliament the opinion of this protocol, which will put into practice effective measures to monitor mobile devices and a better guarantee on such goods between the states participating in this protocol.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution agreeing to the Protocol on specific issues relating to railway rolling stock, annexed to the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment Materials, adopted in Luxembourg on 23 February 2007, on the understanding that the Protocol, by establishing an international system for registering guarantees, will contribute to promoting capital investment in the sector and enhancing the functioning of a genuine mobile rail equipment market in Europe, and is also compatible with EU law and the objectives set out in the 4th railway package and the 2011 White Paper on Transport.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the ratification of this Convention, since this is intended to speed up and protect the investments of railway rolling stock builders against third-country purchasers or credit institutions in order to provide them with greater guarantees of payment. In this way, better regulation and greater legal guarantees are promoted at the international level in a market of importance to Europe as the producer of this type of equipment.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — This Proposal refers to the adoption by the European Union of the Luxembourg Protocol on specific issues relating to railway rolling stock and constitutes an annex to the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment Materials, adopted in Luxembourg on 23 February 2007, a posteriori, as the Railway Protocol. It was signed by the EU by a prior council decision on 10 December 2009. The rapporteur rightly mentions that the proposal under discussion is intrinsically related to the implementation of the fourth railway package, which includes the objective of advancing the path of innovation and investment in this sector at European level, using greener and more sustainable modes of transport. Whereas the Protocol is compatible with EU law, that the choice of legal basis is correct, that the EU has the power to make declarations on certain matters of the Protocol and that the Contracting Parties may make declarations as to the applicability of their rules, I therefore note that the essential conditions for the European Parliament to have approved this proposal in favour of , which I believe is beneficial in creating a genuine market for mobile and sustainable rail equipment in Europe.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because the protocol we are asked to approve is closely linked to the fourth rail package, which deepens the privatisation trend of the railway sector. There is no way I will vote in favour of privatisation of the strategic sectors of the economy, such as rail transport.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – I voted in support of the decision on the approval of the Protocol to the Convention on International Interests in Mobile Equipment on Matters specific to Railway Rolling Stock. According to the proposal, the objective of the Rail Protocol is to facilitate the financing of high-value railway rolling stock by creating a strong international guarantee for creditors. The Commission emphasises that this should not only encourage capital investment in the rail sector, but also benefit the creation of a genuine lease market for mobile railway equipment in Europe. The proposal points out that the Rail Protocol is also consistent with the objective of supporting the shift to greener and more sustainable modes of transport. The United Kingdom has notified the President of the Council that it wishes to take part in the adoption and application of this Decision in accordance with Article 3 of Protocol No 21.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - Since it was on June 12th, 2013. The Commission published a proposal for a Council decision on authorisation on behalf of the European Union, on the international share of rolling stock-specific movable equipment. Furthermore, as on 20 November 2013 The Council adopted the Approval Decision, on behalf of the European Union, the Protocol and on 14 April 2014 requested the consent of the European Parliament, we must look at the facts that would be in the best interests of the European Union when it comes to rail transport. I welcome the objectives of this proposal, which call for fostering innovation and investment in railways.  As a member of the environment committee, I consider this proposal of particular interest, and I welcome the point of proposal which aims to foster a sustainable and green mode of transport such as rail transport.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — We are voting against because legal or natural persons are given the right to claim damages from 'an international system' instead of from the competent courts.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. In accordance with the proposal, the objective of the Rail Protocol is to facilitate the provision of financing for high-value railway rolling stock by creating a strong international guarantee for creditors, whether they are credit sellers or organizations providing credit for such sales. This should encourage not only capital investment in the rail sector, but also contribute to the creation of a genuine market for the rental of mobile equipment in Europe.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I supported this proposal, because I believe it leads to a significant facilitation of the conditions for registration of ownership, improving the safety of conditions and offering the best solutions in case of bankruptcy of private operators and owners of mobile equipment. I consider all proposals, which in this or similar way lead to the removal of administrative barriers and simplification of technical rules on the market, as a positive development worthy of all support.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The Cape Town Convention establishes a uniform regime for the establishment and effects of an international guarantee, namely: guarantee-building contract, title contract of ownership and rental contract on certain mobile equipment – in this case, railway rolling stock. It includes legal provisions that apply to all categories of mobile equipment and a set of specific protocols providing for specific rules for certain equipment. The proposal under discussion is closely related to the implementation of the fourth railway package, which includes the objective of encouraging innovation and investment in the EU railway, with the general trend towards privatisation in the rail sector.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — This agreement would transfer further powers of the national supervisory authorities to the Union and should not only be rejected for this reason, but above all the national supervisory bodies in the financing sector can assess the situation in their own country better than any national or unified European organisation. That is why I did not vote in favour of the Agreement.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I support the accession of the European Union to the so-called Railway Protocol to the Convention on International Safeguards for Mobile Equipment. Its primary objective is to facilitate the financing of high-value rolling stock by creating an exceptionally strong international guarantee for creditors. The seller on credit (and the credit institutions for such sale) will be entitled to a security giving "absolute" priority in respect of such equipment entered in the newly created international register. It will be a system that guarantees the ability to search for established security from anywhere across the EU via the internet, which means that the register will be available 24 hours a day. Such an instrument will certainly bring great benefits and contribute to the development of the European rail industry, including companies operating in the Kujawsko-Pomeranian Voivodeship in Poland involved in the production and repair of rail vehicles for rail transport.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The aim of the proposal is to approve the EU's Protocol on specific issues relating to railway rolling stock, annexed to the Convention on International Guarantees on Mobile Equipment Materials. The EU decided to sign the Railway Protocol and effectively did so in December 2010. The Convention shall apply where the debtor is situated in a Contracting State and strengthens the rights of creditors if the debtor does not comply with his obligations by establishing an international system of creditors which allows creditors to register guarantees for various categories of movable equipment assets and to benefit from rules on priority and enforceability of guarantees. Under the proposal, the objective of the Railway Protocol is to facilitate the financing of high-value railway rolling stock, creating a strong international guarantee for creditors, be they credit sellers or institutions that provide credit for such sales. Since the proposal under discussion is closely related to the implementation of the fourth railway package, with the general trend towards privatisation in the rail sector, we voted against it. \

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. - The Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on Forum Election Agreements is a convention on a matter of private international law and has been drawn up by the Hague Conference on Private International Law. The Convention refers to exclusive forum choice agreements concluded in civil and commercial matters. By these agreements, the two parties agree that any dispute on a particular issue shall be settled by the courts of the State which they determine. In that regard, the purpose of the Convention is similar, at international level, to that of Article 25 of the Brussels I Regulation recast at European level. The provisions of the Convention lay down their scope, define forum choice agreements and regulate jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement issues as well as procedural aspects. I believe that the European Union should participate in this Convention, so I voted in favour.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. - The Hague Convention on Jurisdiction Agreements of 30 June 2005 is an agreement on exclusive jurisdiction agreements concluded in civil or commercial matters within the framework of the Hague Conference on Private International Law. The Convention includes provisions limiting its scope, establishing jurisdiction agreements, jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement, and resolving procedural issues. The European Union has already taken up this private law issue by recasting the Brussels I Regulation. International legal certainty in international exclusive jurisdiction agreements will promote trade between the participating states. For this reason, this Convention should be approved.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. – Whilst I support the principle that there should be freedom in this respect, I was elected as a Member of the European Parliament for a party which seeks withdrawal from the European Union. If this vote had been in a national Parliament, I would have supported such a motion.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, the purpose of which is to support the Hague Convention on Choice of Jurisdiction. This Convention in the field of private international law applies to agreements of exclusive jurisdiction concluded in the field of civil and commercial relations. These are agreements by which both parties agree that any disputes between them on a particular matter will be dealt with in the courts of the state indicated. I agree that the European Union should be involved in the application of this Convention, which was signed in 2009. I support the proposals set out above to encourage the US to ratify the Convention, because if this convention were to be applied on a large scale, it would provide greater legal certainty in the conclusion of exclusive jurisdiction agreements at international level, which would encourage trade between the participating countries.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against the adoption of this convention which, under the pretext of resolving international trade disputes, contributes to the divestiture of States of their judicial sovereignty in favour of a so-called "international justice" with suspect legitimacy.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - The Convention applies in international situations to exclusive for-for election agreements concluded in civil or commercial matters. It seems to me essential at the moment to have a standardisation of international contracts in order to promote trade between states. This will allow for more consistency and a better legal guarantee for exclusive international for agreements.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This 2005 Convention on For Election Agreements, which the EU already signed in 2009, must be adopted here by the European Union. It is a convention under private international law (for now, of which the only country to have signed it is Mexico) that clearly sweeps away the sovereignty of states.  An exclusive for election agreement may be entered into by two or more parties to designate courts (or one or more specific courts) of a contracting state competent for litigation in a particular law report. The convention's objective is to ensure that the courts chosen by the parties to a transaction will experience the dispute and that the resulting judgment will be recognized in other countries. I therefore voted against this recommendation, which rejects any weakening of the sovereignty of the Nation States, including that of my country, France.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this measure, which guarantees greater protection and transparency for consumers.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - The Convention voted on by Parliament governs the recognition and enforcement of dispute resolutions relating to commercial transactions armed by exclusive forum choice agreements. The Convention shall apply to agreements const reached in civil and commercial matters, and shall provide legal certainty by allowing parties to international contracts not only to use the dispute settlement forum of their choice, but also to ensure that the relevant judicial decisions are valid in other States parties. That's why I voted for it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this recommendation in support of the draft Council decision exempting insurance contracts concluded with consumers, thus preventing consumers from inadvertently accepting the choice of court. The declaration annexed to the draft decision formally sets out this exemption and preserves the freedom of the main commercial insurance and reinsurance contracts. The Hague Convention on Choice of Court is a convention in the field of private international law drawn up by the Hague Conference on Private International Law. This Convention shall apply to exclusive jurisdiction agreements concluded in the field of civil-commercial relations. These are agreements by which both parties agree that any disputes between them on a particular matter will be dealt with in the courts of the state indicated. The widespread application of this Convention would help to provide greater legal certainty in the conclusion of exclusive jurisdiction agreements at international level, which would encourage trade between the participating countries. This Convention should therefore be approved.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: In writing. —I voted in favour of this legislative resolution because I believe that the economy and people must live in a global and European legal environment where the decisions of justices taken in a country other than residence have a positive value.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. - The Hague Convention signed on 30 June 2005 states that "a for election agreement allows parties to pre-designate a competent court of a contracting state, to hear disputes born or to be born on the occasion of a certain legal relationship". In principle, the approval of such a convention is an act of judicial sovereignty that must belong exclusively to states recognized by international law and not to a sui generis organization, even with legal personality.  Indeed, the Hague Convention will force the signatory states to accept that a dispute between two parties, be decided by a court under a State party to the convention, whether or not it is a member of the European Union. Once is not customary, the approval by the European Parliament of the Hague Convention, reflects the European Union's desire to have greater foreign policy powers. As a defender of the full sovereignty of France, I have obviously voted against the approval of the Hague Convention by the European Parliament.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - The Convention on Agreements for the Choice of the Court is designed to provide greater legal certainty and predictability for parties involved in international agreements and disputes by creating an optional system for resolving judicial disputes. The objective of the Convention is to promote international trade and investment through enhanced judicial cooperation through the introduction of uniform rules on jurisdiction. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it seeks to strike a balance between the need to ensure that the courts of their choice will resolve the case and the need to allow states to pursue aspects of their public policies, such as respect for the guarantee of exclusive competence of states. The report practically complements the objectives underpinning EU rules on the extension of competence by creating a harmonised set of rules within the EU with regard to third States that will become Contracting Parties to the Convention.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour. The measure protects the consumer on the insurance aspects and provides more certainty in disputes.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The European Parliament voted in favour of the Council's decision to approve, on behalf of the European Union, the Hague Convention on For Election Agreements. These agreements stipulate that both parties agree that any litigation will be referred to the state courts. The convention is very important because it defines for election agreements, covers issues of judicial competence, recognition and enforcement, and also addresses several procedural issues. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the Hague Convection of 30 June 2005 on agreements for the choice of forum. The Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 concerns a sensitive issue of private international law, drawn up by the Hague Conference. The Convention covers exclusive choice agreements concluded in civil and commercial matters by which the parties agree that any dispute arising between them on a given matter will be decided by the courts of the specified State. I agree that the EU should participate in this convention, in view of the increased legal certainty, the basic principle of international law and all national law. This is important in view of the possibility, which must always be stimulated at European level, of promoting exchanges between the participating States. I also agree with the Council's draft decision to exempt insurance contracts with consumers from the scope of the Convention, in order to prevent consumers from unknownly accepting a clause on the choice of forum, which, in addition to being opaque to itself, could lead to further consumer law problems.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — This recommendation regards the choice-of-court in civil and commercial matters, covering jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement issues. I have voted in favour as I welcome greater clarity over choice-of-court agreements.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the Convention because the agreements on the choice of forum will have the effect of ensuring greater legal certainty and thus promoting exchanges between the participating States.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) Legal certainty is a principle which should never be called into question. On the contrary, I believe that every opportunity to reiterate this is a moment of failure for the legal system as a whole. I voted in favour of the Hague Convention in order to make this principle more granite than ever before, so that there is less doubt and more confidence in commercial transactions, both between the parties and with regard to the system that will guarantee the execution of contracts.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The Hague Convention essentially projects the recast Brussels I Regulation at international level with regard to forum agreements in commercial and civil matters. In this way, it is intended to achieve more legal certainty, both for businesses and for consumers. And these, in particular, see their position particularly safeguarded, since insurance contracts are excluded. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the adoption, on behalf of the European Union, of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on agreements for the choice of forum. I am in favour of exclusive court choice agreements concluded in civil and commercial matters, allowing both parties to agree that any dispute between them on a given issue will be decided by the courts of the specified State. I believe that the European Union should participate in this convention, which it signed in 2009, bearing in mind that, at present, the only State to have ratified the Convention is Mexico, but the United States of America is now also deliberating on ratification, and we should encourage them to do so. I am also in favour of the draft Council decision exempting insurance contracts with consumers from the scope of the Convention, in order to prevent consumers from unknownly accepting a clause on the choice of forum.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of this recommendation as it will provide the business community, a strong stakeholder for economic growth, with legal certainty on international exclusive choice of court agreements.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - The Convention concerns a question of private international law or exclusive court choice agreements concluded in civil and commercial matters. These are agreements where two parties agree that any dispute between them on a given issue will be decided by the courts of the specified State. The Convention contains provisions setting out the scope of the Convention, defining agreements for the choice of forum, dealing with matters of jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement and governing various procedural issues. It should be noted that the Council decision exempts consumer insurance contracts from the scope of the Convention in order to prevent consumers from unknownstly accepting a clause on the choice of forum. Widespread acceptance of this Convention would ensure greater legal certainty for exclusive international agreements for the choice of forum and thus encourage trade between participating States. I think it is appropriate to support this convention.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the European Parliament should give its consent to the Council decision ratifying the Convention. The Convention concerns choice of courts agreements in civil and commercial matters and I believe that the European Union should participate in this convention after signing it in 2009.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The Approval by the European Parliament at the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on the for election agreements is a positive act. It will ensure legal certainty without the need to change the legal system already in place in the European Union. The purpose of the Convention is, in fact, identical to Article 25 of the Brussels I regulation at the European level already in place.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Union's accession to the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on agreements for the choice of forum. Many countries have already ratified the Convention, while the United States is now deciding on ratification. I think it would be appropriate for the European Union to approve this convention too, as general accession would ensure greater legal certainty for agreements on the choice of forum and would promote exchanges between the participating states.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The spirit of this text corresponds to a strengthening of the supranational level in areas that fall under the competence of States. The accession of the European Union to such a convention also helps to establish the legal and political position of the EU which I reject, which is why I voted against it.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - We are voting against this proposal because a company can impose in advance on a small trader/producer/consumer from another country that the exclusive seat of their disputes will be a third country other than their home country or their commercial registered office. By that agreement, the possible party may impose on the weak party, in the context of an agreement, a seat of adjudication taking advantage of the need of the latter. The seat may be in Mexico or an EU country, where the transition will be unprofitable for the small party or whose laws or system defend the great interests.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The aim of the Hague Convention is to promote international trade and investment by strengthening judicial cooperation, which involves the introduction of uniform rules. The Convention aims to strike a balance between: (i) the need to assure the parties that only the courts chosen will hear the case and that the judgment given will be recognised and enforced abroad, and (ii) the need to enable States to implement certain aspects of their public policy, relating in particular to the protection of the most defemy parties, protection against serious forms of injustice in certain situations and respect for certain criteria of exclusive competence of states. It thus creates a global resolution mechanism alternative to the existing arbitration system. This report is a recommendation for the adoption of the Convention. The European Commission has stated that it has jurisdiction over all matters governed by the Convention. Therefore, Member States are bound by their conclusion by the EU, which raises some reservations. We recognise, however, the essentially technical nature of this recommendation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - the European Union signed the convention in question in 2009. This Convention concerns agreements on the exclusive jurisdiction of a court concluded in civil and commercial matters. The European Union should accede to this Convention, which is also likely to be ratified by the United States of America in the near future. If the European Union does not accede to the convention in question, it may delay its ratification in other countries as well. Consumer insurance contracts should be excluded from the scope of the Convention.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of the report dealing with the agreements by which two parties agree that any dispute between them on a given matter will be decided by the courts of the specified State. The measure is in defence of the interests of the consumer and provides more certainty in disputes.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision approving, on behalf of the European Union, the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on extrapolation agreements, because a company, such as Carrefour, can impose in advance on a small farmer from Greece that their sole seat for litigation may be a country other than Greece and Germany. Before, a case could be heard in the countries concerned and the advantage was given by whoever was the first to take legal action. With this agreement, the large company may require the other party, during the conclusion of an agreement, to determine the seat of proceedings. The seat may be set in Mexico or in an EU country in which the transition will be unprofitable for the small party or which tends, by law or its system, to defend the great interests. With this agreement, a Greek producer may not be able to hear a case in his country.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on choice-of-court agreements, because I believe that it will encourage the United States of America to proceed with the ratification. Moreover, I believe that EU companies will have more legal certainty when doing business with companies outside the EU. In this way, they can be sure that the judgment given by the chosen court will be recognised and enforced in the countries which applied for it. It will give more clarity and simplification in the business environment.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – The Hague Convention on Jurisdictional Agreements applies to exclusive jurisdiction clauses in civil and commercial matters. In doing so, the courts of a specific State shall act in order to resolve any dispute arising out of specific issues between the two parties. Broad adoption of the Convention would provide greater legal certainty in relation to exclusive international jurisdictional agreements. This would facilitate and make trade between participating States more efficient. In recent years, Hungary relations have strengthened. A predictable commercial legal environment is essential for a successful continuation. That is why the Convention needs to be approved.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. - I supported giving Parliamentʼs consent to this Convention which will give certainty to EU companies trading outwith the EU.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted to approve the Hague Convention of 30 June 2015 on court choice agreements, as accepting the convention means greater legal certainty for European companies trading outside the EU, respecting court choice agreements, and improved trading between participating states. Although currently only Mexico has ratified the convention, I think it is necessary to encourage other states, such as the USA, to ratify it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague Pavel Svoboda's recommendation on the ratification of the Hague Convention on for election agreements. This convention reduces the degree of legal uncertainty for European companies trading outside the EU, while allowing the creation of a harmonised set of rules at European level. After its signing in 2009, the Council must now ratify the treaty, which is what the recommendation agrees to. The text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the approval of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on the for election agreements. The convention aims to enhance legal security and predictability for parties to inter-company agreements and international litigation by creating an optional legal mechanism for resolving disputes worldwide. Thus, this convention ensures that European companies operating outside the EU are ensured that the for election agreements included in their contracts are respected and that the judgments rendered by the courts designated in those agreements can be recognised and carried out in the other States parties to the Convention.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. – I supported giving consent to this convention as it would ensure greater legal certainty for international exclusive choice-of-court agreements and thus foster trade between participating States.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of the convention proposed by Mr Beazley. Pavel Svoboda because I believe that the European Union needs ratification of the Convention, which was already signed in 2009. The Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on agreements for the choice of forum states that any dispute between the parties will be decided by the courts of the specified State. This convention provides greater legal certainty for forum choice agreements and would therefore improve trade between participating States.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - The JURI Commission recommends that the European Parliament give its consent to the Council for the ratification of the Convention on Forum Election Agreements. The Convention regulates the recognition and enforcement of dispute resolutions relating to commercial transactions armed by exclusive forum choice agreements. The Convention will provide legal certainty, as it will allow parties to international contracts not only to use the dispute settlement forum of their choice, but also to ensure that the relevant judicial decisions are valid in other States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on Forum Election Agreements is a convention on a matter of private international law and has been drawn up by the Hague Conference on Private International Law. The Convention refers to exclusive forum choice agreements concluded in civil and commercial matters. By these agreements, the two parties agree that any dispute on a particular issue shall be settled by the courts of the State which they determine. In that regard, the purpose of the Convention is similar, at international level, to that of Article 25 of the Brussels I Regulation recast at European level. The provisions of the Convention lay down their scope, define forum choice agreements and regulate jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement issues as well as procedural aspects. I believe that the European Union should participate in this Convention, so I voted in favour.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - I supported this recommendation, as it provides legal certainty in cases of disputes and ensures compliance with court choice agreements and enforcement and recognition of judgments of the elected court and in cross-border situations.  Furthermore, it is extremely important in international trade risk assessments for companies. The Hague Convention on Court Selection Agreements was concluded on 30 June 2005 under the auspices of the Hague Conference on Private International Law.  It aims to offer greater legal certainty and predictability to parties to company-to-company agreements and international disputes by creating an optional international dispute resolution mechanism in addition to the existing arbitration system, which would result in the promotion of trade between signatory countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting against this Recommendation because, through the proposed Convention, the extrapolation of jurisdiction over loan agreements between Greece and euro area states and between Greece and the EFSF is also legitimised. In this way, the Greek Courts are excluded from the dispute settlement procedure arising from these loan agreements and the relevant jurisdiction is assigned to non-Greek Courts.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I voted for this Report. Widespread up-take of this convention would ensure greater legal certainty for international exclusive choice-of-court agreements and thus foster trade between participating States. Consent should therefore be given to this convention

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Union's accession to the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on agreements for the choice of forum. This measure provides greater protection and transparency for consumers on the insurance aspects and also provides greater legal certainty and consequently facilitates exchanges between participating States.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - The Hague Convention on Agreements for the Choice of The Forum of 30 June 2005 states, under private international law, that any dispute between the parties will be decided by the courts of the specified State. The objective of the Convention reflects, at international level, that contained in Article 25 of the Brussels I Regulation, which is relevant to a purely European sphere. I agree with the rapporteur, Mr Svoboda, that the European Union needs to ratify this convention, which was signed in 2009. It would provide greater legal certainty for exclusive international forum choice agreements and thus improve trade between participating States.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision approving the Hague Convention on jurisdiction agreements. Rapid ratification will lead to greater legal certainty in international exclusive jurisdiction agreements and thus promote trade between participating states. The European Union's economy will thus be boosted.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - The Hague Convention deals with for election agreements (i.e. courts) concluded in civil and commercial matters. In these types of agreements, the parties jointly decide in which country the dispute should be settled, thus allowing the parties to decide which law, what national body of law, should be relevant to resolving their disputes. The aim here is to ratify the Hague Convention on Private International Law already signed by the EU in 2009. Extensive ratification of this convention could provide greater legal certainty for international agreements. It should be noted that so far only Mexico has ratified it. However, there are few safeguards in place to avoid a commercial competition of legislative systems. Faced with these risks of dumping I abstain.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the adoption, on behalf of the European Union, of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on the Forus Election Agreements. The Forus Election Agreements are agreements in which two parties provide that any dispute between them must be decided by the courts of the designated State. I believe that the European Union should participate in this Convention, signed by the Union in 2009. Widespread acceptance of this Convention would ensure greater legal certainty with regard to exclusive fora election agreements, promoting trade between participating States.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this recommendation due to improve the facilitation of trade between the participating countries. Even though Mexico is the only State that has ratified this convention to date, it is expected that others will follow suit. I also welcome the greater clarity over choice-of-court agreements regarding jurisdiction and enforcement.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 provided that "a for election agreement" would allow "parties to pre-designate a competent court of a contracting state, in order to hear disputes born or to be born in a certain law relationship". The Hague Convention therefore clearly ignores the sovereignty of states. Thus, in the event of a dispute between two parties, it will have to be decided by a court under a State party, whether or not it belongs to the European Union. Not wanting France's legal and foreign policy sovereignty to be further weakened and confiscated by the EU, I voted against this recommendation to approve the Hague Convention on for election agreements.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the ratification by the European Union of the for election agreements (The Hague Convention of 30 June 2005). They relate to exclusive civil and commercial for election agreements. These agreements are those by which two parties agree that any dispute between them will be referred to the courts of the stated state. This ratification enhances legal certainty when signing contracts, since the parties will agree in advance on the relevant courts. This decision excludes insurance contracts entered into by consumers, in order to prevent consumers from accepting an election clause of for them without their knowledge.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — The proposal for a Council decision approving the Hague Convention on jurisdiction agreements has the potential to contribute effectively to greater legal certainty. In particular, I link the proposal with the well-founded hope of promoting trade between the participating countries. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The Hague Convention deals with the choice of jurisdictions for disputes in private and commercial international law, and its aim is to ensure greater legal certainty. However, these agreements do not guarantee maximum protection for citizens and consumers; I abstained in that vote.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - I supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the approval on behalf of the European Union of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on agreements on jurisdiction.  I am of the opinion that litigation on certain specific issues must be settled by the national courts specified in the agreement. Accession to the Convention will greatly increase the legal certainty of the parties and promote international trade.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation, which proposes to support the adoption of the Convention. I believe that uniform rules on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments in civil and commercial matters will promote closer links on international trade and investment issues and strengthen judicial cooperation in this area. This is particularly important for EU businesses trading outside the EU, as legal certainty is an important element in risk assessment. It should be noted that the autonomy of countries should be ensured not only at EU level, but also outside the EU, at international level. It is therefore essential to increase legal certainty for companies trading with third countries.  It should be noted that, in order to increase legal certainty in the conclusion of agreements on exclusive jurisdiction at international level, the EU's efforts alone are not sufficient. The US should be encouraged to ratify this Convention. The more states, the Union's main trading partners, ratify this Convention, the greater the benefits will be for business.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I gave my consent to the Council decision to ratify the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on choice of court agreements, which concerns choice of court agreements in civil and commercial matters.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - In view of the fact that the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on agreements for the choice of a forum is a convention on a question of private international law and was drawn up by the Hague Conference on Private International Law, given that the Convention concerns exclusive agreements for the choice of forum concluded in civil and commercial matters, given that at present the only State to have adopted that Convention is Mexico and that the United States is in the process of adopting it Whereas general accession to this Convention would ensure greater legal certainty for exclusive international forum choice agreements and thus encourage trade between participating States, for these reasons I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — This convention should be signed by the sovereign states that wish to do so and not by a body such as the European Union. Taking away from the states their legislative competence is unacceptable and contrary to any democracy. I therefore vote against the adoption of this convention.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I supported Representative Pavel Svoboda's initiative to send a recommendation on the approval of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on agreements on the election of a court to the Council. I would emphasise that the EU's approval of the Convention will ensure greater legal certainty when choosing an international court for agreements and thereby enhance trade between participating countries. I believe that it is important for the EU to work in line with the objectives of the Convention on the Promotion of International Trade and Investment through strengthening judicial cooperation by introducing uniform rules. The aim of the Convention is to offer greater legal certainty and predictability to parties to company agreements and international disputes, by creating an optional international dispute resolution mechanism in addition to the existing arbitration system.  I approve a draft decision of the Council of the European Union that exempts consumer insurance contracts from the Convention, which will prevent beneficiaries from unknowingly agreeing to the court's selection clause. In my view, the EU's approval of the Convention will complement the realisation of the objectives underpinning EU rules on extending competences, creating a harmonised set of rules within the EU in relation to third states that will become Parties to the Convention.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 referred to in the recommendation, which I voted in favour of, concerns a matter of private international law.  Exclusive forum choice agreements are only those concluded in civil and commercial matters. Specifically, these are agreements where two parties agree that any dispute between them, on a given issue, will be decided by the courts of the specified State. The Convention is very clear and the provisions establishing its scope define the agreements for the choice of forum, deal with matters of jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement and regulate various procedural issues that are well structured. It would be desirable for third countries to join this convention as high as possible, because there would undoubtedly be greater legal certainty for exclusive international forum choice agreements and, consequently, smoother exchanges between participating states.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. - Today, in voting, I supported the Hague Convention on Agreements on The Choice of Court, which I had the honour of signing on the European Community's part on 1 April 2009 during the Czech Presidency, when I was Minister of Justice of the Czech Republic. In my opinion, this international convention is extremely important because it will allow exclusive agreements to be concluded on the choice of court, which are concluded in civil and commercial matters. These are agreements in which the two parties agree to settle any dispute between them with an international element by the courts in a designated state. Until now, this rule has only applied between EU states, on the basis of the Brussels I Regulation. The contract will increase the enforceability of the law and increase the legal certainty of the parties to the legal relationship, as they will know who will decide on their dispute and who will recognize and enforce such a decision. The fundamental principle of this Convention shall be the mutual trust of the Contracting States in the activities of their judicial authorities.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — This agreement is a major step forward in resolving cross-border disputes between legal entities in the interests of all parties. Since critical areas such as .B protection of consumers and workers are excluded, German citizens have no fear of discrimination in terms of our legal standards.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — In view of the intensification of international trade, it is indeed necessary to provide clear and predictable legal avenues before public justice, to which the parties to a transaction agree. The Hague Convention on For Election Agreements attempts to do so, which is why I am in favour of it. However, its application remains brief around the world.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution agreeing to the adoption of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on agreements for the election of the fora concluded in civil and commercial matters, because I believe that it is of great relevance in the context of international trade, ensuring respect for private autonomy and the necessary legal certainty in cross-border transactions.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the ratification of this Convention governing the recognition and enforcement of dispute resolutions relating to commercial transactions without exclusive forum choice agreements. The Convention shall apply to agreements const reached in civil and commercial matters and shall provide legal certainty by allowing parties to international contracts not only to use the dispute settlement forum of their choice, but also to ensure that the relevant judicial decisions are valid in other States parties.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — One of the objectives of the European Union is the creation of a common legal area based on the principles of judicial cooperation and mutual recognition of judicial decisions. To that end, the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 established an international regulatory framework for exclusive agreements for the election of the forum, concluded in civil and commercial matters, in which the parties stipulate that any dispute between them must be decided by the courts of the designated State. I therefore considered it important to vote in favour of this recommendation, which approves this Convention on behalf of the European Union, not only for the valuable contribution it makes to the level of the autonomy of the parties in international commercial transactions, giving them predictability and legal certainty, but also by ensuring to the parties that their choice of judicial agreement will be respected and that the decision given by the court of choice will be capable of recognition and enforcement in international cases. The adoption of this Convention by the EU will thus reduce legal uncertainty for European companies operating outside the Union, while retaining those that are their objectives of extending their competence and legal harmonisation in international trade.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour because the measure respects the needs of consumers on the insurance aspects and at the same time provides more certainty in disputes.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the approval of the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on Choice of Court Agreements. The Hague convention concerns exclusive choice-of-court agreements concluded in civil and commercial matters. These are agreements whereby two parties agree that any dispute on a certain issue between them will be settled by the courts of the State specified. Currently, the only State to have ratified the convention is Mexico. However, ratification deliberations are ongoing in the United States of America. I support the opinion that widespread up-take of this convention would ensure greater legal certainty for international exclusive choice-of-court agreements and thus foster trade between participating States.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on court choice agreements. This Convention provides legal certainty in cases of disputes and ensures compliance with court choice agreements and enforcement and recognition of judgments of the elected court and in cross-border situations. Also, the aim of the Hague Convention is to offer greater legal certainty and predictability to parties to agreements between companies and international disputes by creating an optional international dispute resolution mechanism in addition to the existing arbitration system, which would result in stimulating trade between signatory countries.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - Given that the 'Convention on the Election of the Agreement of the Court'' which was concluded on 30 June 2005 and signed by the Union on 1 April 2009, on the basis of The Council Decision 2009/397/EC, it is important that, prior to the approval of the convention on behalf of the European Union, any individual person and company affected by this Convention is protected and that there is no detrimental impact on the same.  Furthermore, I welcome the fact that this Convention would reduce the legal uncertainty of European Union companies trading outside the Union, and this convention will have a harmonised set of rules within the EU.  This Convention applies to all Member States, including Croatia, and as a representative of Croatia in the European Parliament, I support the report for the approval of the Convention because I believe it will greatly help in harmonizing the law for companies belonging to the Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — We are voting against this proposal because, according to it, a company, such as Carrefour, will be able to impose in advance on a small farmer from Greece that the sole seat of their disputes will be a third country, apart from Greece or Germany. Before, the case could only be heard in the countries concerned and the advantage would have been given by whoever was the first to take legal action. However, with this agreement, the large company will be able to require the other party, in the context of the conclusion of the agreement, to determine the seat of proceedings. The seat could be, for example, in Mexico or in an EU country where the transition will be unprofitable for the small part or whose laws or system defend big interests. With such an agreement, a Greek producer will not be able to hear a case in his country.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - This proposed Commission decision excludes insurance contracts entered into by consumers from the scope of the agreement in order to prevent consumers from accepting an election clause of for them without their knowledge. The declaration attached to the draft decision formalizes this exemption and also leaves room for freedom for large commercial insurance and reinsurance contracts. A review statement allows for a new analysis of this reserve in the future. So I voted in favour of the text.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I support the proposal of the rapporteur, who encourages the ratification of the Hague Convention. This applies to private international law, namely choice contracts that would be held accountable by the court in civil and commercial matters.  I agree with the rapporteur's statement that the acceptance of this Convention should ensure legal certainty for international exclusive 'choice-of-court' arrangements and thus encourage exchanges between Member States of the Union. As a positive consequence of ratification, I also hold the possibility to consequently develop a more consistent level of implementation of judgments, because common rules would extend the scope to international law.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I am voting in favour of eu participation on 30 June 2005. The Hague Convention, as it provides greater legal certainty for international judicial choice agreements while promoting trade between the participating countries, and in particular helps small and medium-sized businesses to feel safer when expanding outside the European Union. I also support the exemption from insurance contracts under this Convention, as this prevents consumers from choosing a court without their own knowledge. It is essential that consumers are protected from disadvantages when the forces of the parties to the contract are not equal.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on Forum Election Agreements is a convention on a matter of private international law and has been drawn up by the Hague Conference on Private International Law. The Convention refers to exclusive forum choice agreements concluded in civil and commercial matters. By these agreements, the two parties agree that any dispute on a particular issue shall be settled by the courts of the State which they determine. In that regard, the purpose of the Convention is similar, at international level, to that of Article 25 of the Brussels I Regulation recast at European level. The provisions of the Convention lay down their scope, define forum choice agreements and regulate jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement issues as well as procedural aspects. I believe that the European Union should participate in this Convention, so I voted in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The purpose of the Convention is to promote international trade and investment by strengthening judicial cooperation, which involves the introduction of uniform rules on jurisdiction, on the basis of exclusive court election agreements, and on the recognition and enforcement of judgments given by the courts chosen by the Contracting Parties. According to the Council proposal, the adoption of the CONVENTION by the EU will reduce legal uncertainty for European companies operating outside the EU by ensuring that the choice of judicial agreements included in their contracts is respected and that judgments given by the courts designated in those agreements will be eligible for recognition and enforcement by the other Contracting Parties to the Convention. Overall, the adoption of the CONVENTION by the EU will complement the achievement of the objectives underlying EU rules on the extension of competence by establishing a harmonised set of rules in the EU in relation to third countries that will become Contracting Parties to the Convention. It is part of the creation of a common judicial area based on the principle of mutual recognition of judicial decisions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since, in my view, the speedy ratification of the Council decision approving the Hague Convention would ensure greater legal certainty in international exclusive jurisdiction agreements and, inter alia, promote trade between the participating States, I voted in favour of the request.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The express objective of the Convention is to promote international trade and investment by strengthening judicial cooperation through the introduction of uniform rules on jurisdiction on the basis of exclusive court election agreements and on the recognition and enforcement of judgments given by the courts chosen by the Contracting Parties.
